title: Admit Trends
text:
Average scores for students by decision
    
    
    
      Decision
      Test Score
      Writing Score
      GPA
      Work Experience
      Volunteer Level
    
  
  
    Admit
960.2
91.2
3.74
2.1
2.2
    Waitlist
865.7
82.5
3.49
2.2
2.6
    Decline
780.1
74.1
3.25
2.2
2.6
  
  
  




Admitted students had an average test score of 960.2, an average writing score of 91.2, and an average GPA of 3.74, all three measures being higher than students who were waitlisted or declined. Admitted students had an average of 2.1 years of work experience and an average volunteer level of 2.2, similar to students who were waitlisted or declined.

Exploring Student Statistics Based on Admit Decision
For test score, writing score, and GPA there is a visible trend of admitted students having the highest average and declined students having the lowest average.















For work experience and volunteer level there is no visible trend.












Proportions of Admissions Based on Each Variable

Demographics
Male and female students had identical admit, waitlist, and decline rates.





There are differences in admit, waitlist, and decline rates between states.







Scores
The students with the highest GPAs had the highest rates of admission to the internship. All students with GPAs of 3.9 or greater were admitted while the majority of students with GPAs of 3.6 or higher were admitted. No students with GPAs below 3.5 were admitted.





All students that scored above 900 on the test were admitted and all students that were waitlisted scored between 800 and 900.





All students with a writing score greater than 90 were admitted while the majority of students with a writing score below 90 were waitlisted or declined.







Experience
There is no visible trend when it comes to admit rates and work experience or volunteer level.













Correlation Between Variables
The most strongly correlated variables are test score, GPA, and writing score.







Relationship Between Test Score and Other Variables

Demographics
Average test score does not differ for male and female students.





The three states with the highest test score averages (California, Florida, and Colorado) also had the highest admit rates for students.







Scores





There is one student with a low test score and high GPA who was admitted. All other admitted students were in the highest band of test scores (above 950).





This student also has a high writing score and is the only student with a low test score and high writing score to be admitted.


Experience





Students with a wide range of work experiences were admitted, waitlisted, and declined. There does not appear to be a relationship between work experience and test score.





Students with a wide range of volunteer levels were admitted, waitlisted, and declined. There does not appear to be a relationship between volunteer level and test score.



Conclusion
Based on the trends explored above, the most important consideration for this company’s hiring team seemed to be the students’ test scores. With few exceptions, using only the test score for a student we can make a strong prediction for whether or not they were admitted.

title: Our Goals and Purpose
text:
In this report we will explore trends in acceptance to a summer internship based on student demographics, scores, and experience. The purpose of the report is to increase decision transparency and increase internship support and resources for students. We will do this through the following three goals:
1. Identify trends within decision groups.
This will help us understand what was making a candidate successful.
2. Identify the most important aspect of a student’s application
This will help us understand what students should focus on.
3. Identify how the university can better support students
This will allow us to give tangible recommendations to universities to help students better prepare for internships.

title: Analysing the Waitlist and Decline Groups
text:
After exploring some of the trends between students who were admitted versus students who were declined or waitlisted, we felt it was also important to look more at what the difference was between a student getting declined or waitlisted. First, here are the differences between the averages of all of the testing scores, GPA, volunteer levels, and work experience between these two groups.






  
    
    
      Decision
      GPA
      Work Experience
      Test Score
      Writing Score
      Volunteer Level
    
  
  
    Decline
3.252500
2.200000
780.1071
74.14286
2.571429
    Waitlist
3.486522
2.213043
865.6957
82.52174
2.608696
  
  
  




From this table, we can see the students on the waitlist have higher scores in each categories. There appear to be bigger differences between GPA, Test Scores, and Writing Scores, than in work experience and volunteer level. We can do a statistical test to test for a difference in means.






  
    
    
      Variable
      p-value
    
  
  
    GPA
0.002
    WorkExp
0.978
    TestScore
< 0.001
    WritingScore
< 0.001
    VolunteerLevel
0.938
  
  
  




From this test, we see that there is a statistically significant difference in means between the decline and waitlist groups in GPA, Test Score, and Writing Score. These are the variables we will explore further to see how different they are between the waitlist/decline groups.

title: Analysing the Waitlist and Decline Groups
text:
Exploring Significant Variables





In terms of GPA, we see that the waitlisted students’ GPAs range between 3.20 and 3.59, whereas the declined students’ GPAs are across the board.





In this exploration of the test scores for waitlisted and declined students, we see that declined students tended to have lower test scores, with scores typically being below 800, whereas all waitlisted students had scores between 850-870.





We see a similar trend in the writing scores, with declined students typically having scores lower than 80 and waitlisted students typically having scores above 80.
It is important to note that there are students who have been declined who have higher GPAs, test scores, and writing scores than many of the waitlisted students. Why may that be? Let’s explore this trend further below.

Utah

All of these candidates are relatively similar across the board, but all received different decisions. I think many would be surprised that candidate 1 got declined. As we have seen, a 3.84 is well within the range for acceptance. Their test scores and writing scores were also on the higher end of the waitlist range. Though lower than the accepted candidate 2, the scores are by no means poor and are well within the waitlist range at least. The question remains, why did this person get declined and not admitted, let alone waitlisted? The main difference we see between this candidate and the admitted and waitlisted candidates is the volunteer score. While volunteer score may be not significant for overall difference in groups, on an individual basis, this internship may be looking for students who put more effort into serving their community and volunteering. This theory would explain their declined status.

title: Recommendations
text:
Our recommendations are as follows:

Communication will increase transperency

Create a report for students on these internship admission trends
Organize internship advising to increase feedback.

Test Prep Course

Test Score was the most correlated variable with admission so creating a test prep class would help students increase their scores.

Writing Prep Course

Writing Score was strongly positively correlated with admission so creating a test prep course would help students increase their writing scores.

Increase the number of required English classes

Increasing the number of required English classes would improve student’s writing and writing scores.

title: General Trends
text: The dataset contains information about 79 students applying to an internship. There are eight variables in the dataset related to a student’s background, various test scores, and the internship hiring decision. These six variables are the state the student is from, gender, GPA, test score, writing test score, the number of years of work experience they have,the level of effort they put into volunteering, and their admission decision (admitted, waitlisted, or declined). We will first investigate trends by admission decision in these variables as well as how correlated they are with the admission decision. These trends will help inform the board of the most important factors that internship hiring committes are using.

title: General Trends
text:
Admission Decisions
The same percentage of students were admitted and declined, 35.4%. Slighly less students, 29.1%, were waitlisted. Overall, admissions decisions were split relatively equally across types of decisions.

title: General Trends
text:
Correlations
For all of the variables except the states variable, we can compute correlation coefficients. The most correlated variable is test score. We can infer that the student’s with the highest test scores are most likely to be admitted. However, other variables may contribute to internship decisions. Gender was perfectly uncorrelated with internship decisions so we can infer that gender does not matter in the applicant process.
Test Score, Writing Score, and GPA are all positively correlated with internship decisions and are also correlated with each other. Volunteer Level and Work Experience are negatively correlated with admission decision and negatively correlated with eachother.

title: General Trends
text:
State
Applicants came from 10 states, with Florida having the most applicants, followed by Colorado and California. California had the highest percentage of admits compared to other states. No students from states with only one applicant were admitted. All four applicants from Virginia were declined. Overall, admission decisions appear to vary across states so we can assume that the state a applicant is from could affect their admission decision.

title: General Trends
text:
Gender
There are 45 male applicants and 34 female applicants. The proportion of admits, waitlists, and declines are nearly identical across genders. This shows that gender is uncorrelated with admission decision.

title: General Trends
text:
GPA
GPA is positively correlated with internship decision as shown by admitted students having the highest test scores, followed by waitlisted students and declined students. Declined students appear more uniform across the GPA bands compared to waitlisted or admitted students.

title: General Trends
text:
Test Scores
Internship Decisions are strongly positively correlated with test scores, as shown by the clear divisions of test scores among the groups besides a few outliers. Admitted students have the highest GPA, followed by waitlisted students and declined students.

title: General Trends
text:
Writing Scores
Internship Decisions are positively correlated with writing test scores. Admitted students have the highest writing scores, followed by waitlisted students and declined students besides a few outliers.

title: General Trends
text:
Work Experience
By observing the plot below, we can see that work experience is uncorrelated with admission decision.

title: General Trends
text:
Volunteer Experience
By observing the plot below, we can see that volunteer experience is uncorrelated with admission decision.

text:
